checkpoint-1.caption: Students can access presentation content, regardless of their sensory abilities.

table.task: Use Google Slides' built-in slide layouts to ensure proper reading order.
Provide unique and descriptive slide titles for each slide.
Add alternative text to all images, charts, and graphics.
Include detailed explanations of complex visuals in speaker notes.
Ensure sufficient color contrast between text and background.
Avoid using color alone to convey information or meaning.
Use legible sans-serif fonts (like Arial or Verdana) at 24pt or larger for body text.
Include accurate captions for videos embedded in slides.
Provide transcripts for audio content or describe it in speaker notes.

checkpoint-2.caption: Students can navigate and interact with presentations regardless of how they use computers.

table.task: Maintain logical reading order by using built-in layouts and avoiding overlapping elements.
Use descriptive link text instead of generic phrases like 'Click here'.
Minimize or avoid automatic transitions and animations.
Allow students to control pacing when viewing slides.
Avoid creating custom text boxes that may disrupt reading order.

checkpoint-3.caption: Students can easily understand the content and navigate through presentations.

table.task: Use clear and concise language appropriate to students' reading level.
Define unfamiliar terms and abbreviations when first introduced.
Structure content with bulleted or numbered lists for clarity.
Organize sections with clear, descriptive headings.
Provide context for visual elements and avoid vague references.
Use sequential labels (like 'Part 1 of 3') when covering the same topic across multiple slides.

checkpoint-4.caption: Students can access presentations using different technologies and tools that help them learn.

table.task: Use accessibility checkers like Grackle Slides to scan for issues.
Share presentations in accessible formats such as publishing to the web.
Provide alternative formats of the presentation content when needed.
Use simple tables and describe their content clearly.
Convert complex visuals into simpler images with comprehensive alternative text.
